abstract.para: This document describes the procedures for obtaining, installing, and incorporating the mapplet Java applet into MapServer web pages.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The mapplet Java applet provides interface enhancements to web pages driven by either the MapServer CGI program or any MapScript utility. This document describes how to add the mapplet to existing MapServer pages.
This document assumes no previous knowledge or experience with Java programming or applet installation. It does, however, assume the following:

listitem.para: Familiarity with fundamental aspects of managing the MapServer software and the web server.

Basic familiarity with the JavaScript browser scripting language. If this is a limitation, JavaScript reference materials can be found on the web (the Netscape JavaScript documentation pages are a good place to start).
The ability to download and unpack (unzip) archive files (e.g., .tar or .zip files) from the internet.
The MapServer/MapScript software is installed and functioning on a web server.

The MapServer demo application is running on your server (see both the download and documentation sections of the MapServer web-site). If you don't have the demo running, but you do have your own MapServer application in place, you probably won't have any difficulty adapting the instructions given here to your application.

sect1.title: Mapplet Features
sect1.para: The mapplet adds the following functionality to MapServer/MapScript pages:

listitem.para: Users can "drag a box" over a map using their mouse and then zoom in to the extent defined by the box.
Users can "drag a box" over a map using their mouse and execute attribute queries for all features that intersect the box.
Requests for new maps can be loaded directly into the currently displayed page, without reloading the rest of the page.
The coordinates of the cursor location can be displayed in the status bar of the browser. (see http://www.kralidis.ca/gis/mapserv/mapplet/howto.htm for details)

sect1.title: Obtaining the Software
sect1.para:
The mapplet can be obtained at
http://MapServer.gis.umn.edu/contributed.html. Click on the mapplet link and save the zip file to a local disk.

sect2.title: Unpacking the Archive
sect2.para: The first step toward installation involves unpacking the archive file you just downloaded. How you go about this will depend on your operating system. If you run into problems unpacking the archive, contact your system administrator for help.

sect2.title: Positioning the Class File
sect2.para: Once you have successfully unpacked the archive, you will find three new files: mapplet.class, mapplet.java, and evalThread.class. The two .class files constitute the Java byte code that you need in order to incorporate the applet into your pages. The mapplet.java file is the Java source code for the applet. This file is included for the benefit of the curious, or for those who might want to modify the applet in some way, but it is not required for our purposes here. Please note that if you do modify the code, you are encouraged to submit your modified source file to MapServer-info@lists.gis.umn.edu.
To make the applet available to your server, you need simply to place the class files somewhere in your web document tree. For example, if your document tree is rooted at
/usr/local/htdocs,
then you might make add a couple of subdirectories under htdocs so that you get a path like
Then place the class files in the mapplet subdirectory.

tip.para: Though not required, it is generally good practice to store the class files for different applets in separate subdirectories within your document tree.

sect2.para: Note that the class files themselves and the directory in which you place them all need to be accessible and readable by the user that your web server runs as (often user "nobody"). Make sure that the file and directory permissions are properly set, and that the web server is properly configured for this.

sect1.title: Integrating the mapplet with an existing MapServer application
sect1.para: Now that the class files are in a web-accessible space, they can easily be integrated into a MapServer application. We'll use the MapServer demo as an example.
The only changes will be to the html template file that defines how your map pages are displayed. For the MapServer demo, this is the file demo.html. There are essentially four steps:

listitem.para: add a name attribute to the form that controls the map interface,
add a couple of hidden variables to the form,
add a couple of small JavaScript functions to the <head> section,
replace the output map image definition with the applet definition.

sect1.para: Each of these steps is addressed separately below.

sect2.title: Add hidden variables to the form
sect2.para: Next, we need to establish two html form variables that will be passed back and forth between the applet and the JavaScript functions. Add the following lines just after the form definition that we doctored in the previous step:
sect2.programlisting: <input type="hidden" name="imgxy" value="299.5 299.5"> <input type="hidden" name="imgbox" value="-1 -1 -1 -1">
sect2.para: Note that the name attributes for these variables must be typed exactly as shown. The imgxy variable is used to communicate the position of a user's mouse click. The imgbox variable is used to communicate the bounds of a box the user drags with their mouse. The values for both variables are given in terms of image pixel coordinates.

In this step we have initialized the two variables and assigned default values to them. Reasonable default values were determined from the output map image size, set in demo.map to 600x600 pixels. The imgxy coordinate pair is set to the center of the map image, less half a pixel in both the x and y directions. The imgbox pixel coordinates are set to -1 all around, which translates essentially to "no box". Generally speaking, these default values will be replaced in accordance with the user's mouse actions before they are passed to the applet.

sect2.title: Add JavaScript functions
sect2.para: Now we need to add two JavaScript functions to enable communication with the applet. Put these in the <head> section of demo.html, which looks like this by default:
Change that to look like this:
sect2.programlisting:
<head><title>MapServer Demo Interface</title>
      
      <SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JavaScript">

        function mapplet_apply(name, minx, miny, maxx, maxy, redraw) {
          document.mapserv.imgbox.value = minx + " " + miny + " " + maxx + " " + maxy;
          document.mapserv.imgxy.value = minx + " " + miny;
        }

        function mapplet_error(message) {
          alert(message);
        } 

      </SCRIPT>

      </head>
sect2.para: Note the use of "mapserv" on the left side of the assignment statements in the mapplet_apply function:

This is the name attribute that we assigned to the form above. The mapplet_apply function sets the values of the hidden variables we established earlier, and that the mapplet_error function provides a means for the applet to pass error messages out to the user. However, you don't even really need to understand the functions, as you will never call them yourself - that is up to the applet.

sect3.title: A Closer Look

listitem.para:
Specifies the path, relative to the html document root, to the directory containing the needed class file(s). If you put your class files in a directory structure other than /java/mapplet, you will need to change the codebase attribute accordingly.
You can also use a url for the codebase attribute, so that the class files could actually be located just about anywhere on the internet.
Specifies the name of the class file that is to be executed.
Defines the width (in pixels) of the space to be allocated to the applet on the html page. This value should be the same as the width of your output map image, which is set to 600 in demo.map.
Defines the height (in pixels) of the space to be allocated to the applet on the html page. This value should be the same as the height of your output map image.
Assigns a name to the applet for use within the html page. This is handy for use in referring to the applet within javaScript code.
Permits the Java applet to access JavaScript functions (required for the mapplet). Accessing JavaScript when the MAYSCRIPT attribute is not specified results in an exception.

sect3.para: Parameters to be passed to the applet are specified in <param> tags embedded between the opening and closing <applet> tags. Here we have defined only one:

listitem.para: Specifies the map image to be loaded into the applet. Must be a fully-qualified URL. The "[host]" and "[img]" specifiers used here are standard MapServer template substitutions, and will be swapped out for the appropriate values when the MapServer parses demo.html.

sect1.title: A First Run
sect1.para: When you have made the changes to demo.html detailed in the previous section, you will be able to load the modified version into your browser. Load the front page and hit the Initialize button. You can now specify a zoom extent by dragging a box over the map. You'll need to have the Browse map button on, and hit the Refresh/Query button in order to make the box zoom take effect.
What's more, if you turn on the Query multiple features button, drag a box, and hit the Query/Refresh button, you'll get back results for all of the features that intersect the bounds of your box.
However, if you turn on the Query feature button and try to get information on some feature, you'll probably notice a couple of things:

listitem.para: You don't get "instant results" when you click on a feature in the map like you used to. A small crosshair appears at the point of your mouse click, but that's about it. You have to make the effort of going over and clicking on the Refresh/Query button before you actually get results back.

If you try dragging a box and then hit the Refresh/Query button, you get a different error message:
mapserv(): Web application error. Query mode needs a point, imgxy and mapxy are not set.

sect1.para: Is this the experience you want for your users? Likely not. The next section will explain how to circumvent these problems with a bit of JavaScript code.

sect2.title: Turning Box Dragging On and Off
sect2.para: It is logical to drag a box across a part of the map to zoom in, or to select objects to query. But what about zooming out (mode=browse, zoomdir=-1), or re-centering the map (mode=browse, zoomdir=0)? In these operations the box doesn't do us much good. Worse yet, dragging a box in either of these situations would cause a zoom-in regardless of the zoomdir setting.

sect1.title: Optional Mapplet Parameters
sect1.para: The "image" parameter must be specified in order for the mapplet to function. There are several optional parameters that can be passed as a means of customizing your mapplet appearance and functionality. The syntax for specifying these parameters in demo.html is the same as shown above. A tag with the general form
must appear between the opening and closing applet tags. A list of the optional Mapplet parameters, their purpose and valid values is given below.

listitem.para: Specifies how far (in pixels) a user needs to drag their mouse before the mapplet will believe that they are actually dragging a box. This prevents poorly-executed single-clicks at the mouse from being interpreted as dragged boxes. Values should be integers. Default is five.

Specifies the color to use when drawing the mouse-dragged box or the mouse-clicked crosshair cursor. Color values may be specified using either a comma-delimited RGB triplet (for example, value="255,255,255" draws a white box), or the English name for one of thirteen predefined colors (black, blue, cyan, darkGray, gray, green, lightGray, magenta, orange, pink, red, white or yellow). Default is red.
Specifies the thickness (in pixels) of the line to use in drawing the box (does not affect the crosshair cursor). Values should be integers. Default is one.
Specifies the radius (in pixels) of the crosshair cursor. Values should be integers. Default is four.

Enables/disables browser status-line reporting of coordinates for the current location of the mouse cursor. Valid values are "on" and "off". Default is "off". Note that additional JavaScript functions are required in order for this to work.

Enables/disables box drawing. Valid values are "on" and "off". Default is "on". If set to "off", any mouse-button action inside the mapplet interface will always be represented by the crosshair cursor.
Specifies an image to display while the mapplet is working. Value given must be a fully-qualified URL. Generally only useful when used with the swap applet method.
